texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After working with some RHEL 5 servers fairly regularly, I noticed a reduction in Apache 2.2 performance when many connections were made to the server. There were messages like these streaming into the access_log as well:
texts.text: After working with some RHEL 5 servers fairly regularly, I noticed a reduction in Apache 2.2 performance when many connections were made to the server. There were messages like these streaming into the access_log as well:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On servers with ipv6 enabled, you might see a line like this one:
texts.text: On servers with ipv6 enabled, you might see a line like this one:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I began to wonder why Apache was making these connections back onto itself and initiating a
texts.text: I began to wonder why Apache was making these connections back onto itself and initiating a

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When the Apache HTTP Server manages its child processes, it needs a way to wake up processes that are listening for new connections. To do this, it sends a simple HTTP request back to itself. This request will appear in the access_log file with the remote address set to the loop-back interface (typically 127.0.0.1 or ::1 if IPv6 is configured). If you log the User-Agent string (as in the combined log format), you will see the server signature followed by "(internal dummy connection)" on non-SSL servers. During certain periods you may see up to one such request for each httpd child process.
texts.text: When the Apache HTTP Server manages its child processes, it needs a way to wake up processes that are listening for new connections. To do this, it sends a simple HTTP request back to itself. This request will appear in the access_log file with the remote address set to the loop-back interface (typically 127.0.0.1 or ::1 if IPv6 is configured). If you log the User-Agent string (as in the combined log format), you will see the server signature followed by "(internal dummy connection)" on non-SSL servers. During certain periods you may see up to one such request for each httpd child process.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These requests are perfectly normal and you do not, in general, need to worry about them. They can simply be ignored.
texts.text: These requests are perfectly normal and you do not, in general, need to worry about them. They can simply be ignored.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sure, I could easily ignore the requests, but the requests were increasing the load on my server more than I liked. Apache's documentation suggested omitting the lines from the logs by adding the following to the Apache configuration:
texts.text: Sure, I could easily ignore the requests, but the requests were increasing the load on my server more than I liked. Apache's documentation suggested omitting the lines from the logs by adding the following to the Apache configuration:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: lines ensures that the data won't show up in your access logs. However, you'll still end up with
texts.text: lines ensures that the data won't show up in your access logs. However, you'll still end up with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Directory index forbidden by Options directive: /var/www/html/
texts.text: Directory index forbidden by Options directive: /var/www/html/

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: filling up your error_logs. A quick search revealed a  handy mod_rewrite  rule to get rid of these requests as quickly as possible with the lowest effort required from Apache:
texts.text: filling up your error_logs. A quick search revealed a  handy mod_rewrite  rule to get rid of these requests as quickly as possible with the lowest effort required from Apache:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, the requests to the localhost should receive a 403 immediately. Since you can't keep Apache from sending all of these requests to itself, the best you can do is respond to them in a manner that requires the lowest possible resources.
texts.text: At this point, the requests to the localhost should receive a 403 immediately. Since you can't keep Apache from sending all of these requests to itself, the best you can do is respond to them in a manner that requires the lowest possible resources.
